annotator_metadata.Steps:
1. Go to arxiv.org and navigate to the Advanced Search page.
2. Enter "AI regulation" in the search box and select "All fields" from the dropdown.
3. Enter 2022-06-01 and 2022-07-01 into the date inputs, select "Submission date (original)", and submit the search.
4. Go through the search results to find the article that has a figure with three axes and labels on each end of the axes, titled "Fairness in Agreement With European Values: An Interdisciplinary Perspective on AI Regulation".
5. Note the six words used as labels: deontological, egalitarian, localized, standardized, utilitarian, and consequential.
6. Go back to arxiv.org
7. Find "Physics and Society" and go to the page for the "Physics and Society" category.
8. Note that the tag for this category is "physics.soc-ph".
9. Go to the Advanced Search page.
10. Enter "physics.soc-ph" in the search box and select "All fields" from the dropdown.
11. Enter 2016-08-11 and 2016-08-12 into the date inputs, select "Submission date (original)", and submit the search.
12. Search for instances of the six words in the results to find the paper titled "Phase transition from egalitarian to hierarchical societies driven by competition between cognitive and social constraints", indicating that "egalitarian" is the correct answer.
annotator_metadata.Tools:
1. Web browser
2. Image recognition tools (to identify and parse a figure with three axes)

problem: I’m researching species that became invasive after people who kept them as pets released them. There’s a certain species of fish that was popularized as a pet by being the main character of the movie Finding Nemo. According to the USGS, where was this fish found as a nonnative species, before the year 2020? I need the answer formatted as the five-digit zip codes of the places the species was found, separated by commas if there is more than one place.
constraints: Time constraint: Before the year 2020.

Logical constraint: The USGS provides information on where the species was found as a nonnative species.
Physical constraint: The places where the species was found are locations with specific zip codes.

problem:
Here's a fun riddle that I think you'll enjoy.

You have been selected to play the final round of the hit new game show "Pick That Ping-Pong". In this round, you will be competing for a large cash prize. Your job will be to pick one of several different numbered ping-pong balls, and then the game will commence. The host describes how the game works.

A device consisting of a winding clear ramp and a series of pistons controls the outcome of the game. The ramp feeds balls onto a platform. The platform has room for three ping-pong balls at a time. The three balls on the platform are each aligned with one of three pistons. At each stage of the game, one of the three pistons will randomly fire, ejecting the ball it strikes. If the piston ejects the ball in the first position on the platform the balls in the second and third position on the platform each advance one space, and the next ball on the ramp advances to the third position. If the piston ejects the ball in the second position, the ball in the first position is released and rolls away, the ball in the third position advances two spaces to occupy the first position, and the next two balls on the ramp advance to occupy the second and third positions on the platform. If the piston ejects the ball in the third position, the ball in the first position is released and rolls away, the ball in the second position advances one space to occupy the first position, and the next two balls on the ramp advance to occupy the second and third positions on the platform.

The ramp begins with 100 numbered ping-pong balls, arranged in ascending order from 1 to 100. The host activates the machine and the first three balls, numbered 1, 2, and 3, advance to the platform. Before the random firing of the pistons begins, you are asked which of the 100 balls you would like to pick. If your pick is ejected by one of the pistons, you win the grand prize, $10,000.

Which ball should you choose to maximize your odds of winning the big prize? Please provide your answer as the number of the ball selected.
constraints: The ramp begins with 100 numbered ping-pong balls in ascending order from 1 to 100.
The first three balls (1, 2, and 3) are initially placed on the platform.
Each piston can randomly fire at each stage of the game.
When a piston ejects the ball in the first position, the balls in the second and third positions advance one space.
When a piston ejects the ball in the second position, the ball in the first position is released and rolls away, while the ball in the third position advances two spaces.
When a piston ejects the ball in the third position, the ball in the first position is released and rolls away, while the ball in the second position advances one space.
The next two balls on the ramp advance to occupy the second and third positions on the platform if a ball is ejected from either of these positions.
There are only three balls on the platform at any given time.
solutions: Next step: Determine the expected outcome for each possible choice of numbered ping-pong balls. Analyze how many of the 100 balls would be ejected by the pistons if a particular ball is chosen and which position it will occupy on the platform after one piston firing cycle. This analysis will help identify the best choice of ball to maximize the chances of winning the grand prize.

problem: In July 2, 1959 United States standards for grades of processed fruits, vegetables, and certain other products listed as dehydrated, consider the items in the "dried and dehydrated section" specifically marked as dehydrated along with any items in the Frozen/Chilled section that contain the whole name of the item, but not if they're marked Chilled. As of August 2023, what is the percentage (to the nearest percent) of those standards that have been superseded by a new version since the date given in the 1959 standards?

Physical constraint: The standards refer to specific products with listed grades, which have a physical presence.
Contextual constraint: The standards are for grades of processed fruits, vegetables, and certain other products.
Quantitative constraint: The percentage of superseded standards is required as output (to the nearest percent).

problem: Using the Biopython library in Python, parse the PDB file of the protein identified by the PDB ID 5wb7 from the RCSB Protein Data Bank. Calculate the distance between the first and second atoms as they are listed in the PDB file. Report the answer in Angstroms, rounded to the nearest picometer.
constraints: Time constraint: Parse the PDB file within a reasonable time frame (e.g., 10-15 minutes).
Resource constraint: Availability of Biopython library in Python, with sufficient memory and computational resources to handle large data files.
Dependency constraint: Prerequisite knowledge of Python programming language and Biopython library usage.
Logical constraint: Correct interpretation of PDB file format and structure information (e.g., atom identifiers, coordinates).
Physical constraint: None relevant for this problem.
solutions:
The next step is:

Import the Biopython library and load the PDB file using the `fetch_pdb` function from the `PDB` module. This will allow you to access the atomic coordinates of the protein.

Example:
```
from Bio.PDB import PDBList, PDB
pdb_id = "5wb7"
p = PDBList()
structure = p.get_structure(pdb_id)
```
The next step is:

Get the first and second atoms from the structure using the `get_atoms` method. You can use a loop or list comprehension to extract the atoms.

Example:
```
atoms = [residue for residue in structure.get_list() if isinstance(residue, PDB.Residue)]
first_atom = atoms[0].get_atoms()
second_atom = atoms[1].get_atoms()
```
The next step is:

Calculate the distance between the first and second atoms using the `calc_distance` function from the `Bio.PDB.calculate` module. This will give you the distance in nanometers, which you can then convert to Angstroms.

Example:
```
from Bio.PDB.calculate import calc_distance
distance_nm = calc_distance(first_atom[0], second_atom[0])
```

problem: In the video https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=L1vXCYZAYYM, what is the highest number of bird species to be on camera simultaneously?
constraints: **Time constraint**: The video is 4 minutes and 30 seconds long.
**Resource constraint**: There is only one camera capturing the bird species on screen at any given time.
**Dependency constraint**: Each bird species appears on camera in a specific sequence, determined by its natural behavior (e.g., when it flies or roosts).
**Logical constraint**: The number of bird species on camera simultaneously cannot exceed the maximum capacity of the camera's field of view.
**Physical constraint**: The location and distance between birds affect their visibility on camera; larger birds may block smaller ones, reducing the number of species visible at once.

**Contextual detail**: The video features a variety of bird species with different behaviors (e.g., flying, perching, foraging), which impact their likelihood of being captured by the camera simultaneously.

constraints: The bird feeder is filled with seeds for at least 7 days before filming, allowing for a diverse range of species to visit.
The camera is positioned in a way that captures birds visiting the feeder from sunrise to sunset (approximately 6:00 AM - 5:00 PM).
A total of 15 different bird feeders are used in the experiment, each with its unique characteristics attracting specific bird species.
The filming takes place during the peak migratory season for songbirds in North America (late August to early November).
No human interaction or disturbance is allowed within a 10-meter radius of the bird feeder during filming.
A total of 3 different types of seeds are used, including sunflower seeds, safflower seeds, and Nyjer seeds.
The camera records at a resolution of 1080p with a frame rate of 30 frames per second.
There is a 10-minute gap between consecutive filming sessions to allow for bird species to change and the feeder to be refilled.
A minimum of 3 cameras are used to capture simultaneous footage of different angles, ensuring no blind spots or coverage gaps.

annotator_metadata.Steps:
1. Searched "NCATS PubChem compound database" on Google.
2. Opened "PubChem" on the NCATS NIH website.
3. Clicked on the "PubChem Compound" link.
4. Clicked on the "Classification Browser" link.
5. Expanded "Food Additives and Ingredients" in the list.
6. Clicked on the number link next to "Food Additive Status".
7. Opened the filters and set them to maximum 100 g/mol weight, minimum 6 heavy atoms, maximum 1 H-bond acceptor, complexity 10-15.
8. Opened the resulting "HEXANE" page.
9. Scrolled to 10.6 Pharmacology and Biochemistry > Transformations.
10. Opened the two enzyme transformations' pages (CYP2B6 and CYP2E1).
11. Opened each one's gene-chemical co-occurrences full list.
12. Opened each chemical they shared a co-occurrence with.
13. Compared the weights to find the heaviest (Midazolam).
14. Noted its PubChem CID (4192).

problem:
I need to fact-check a citation. This is the citation from the bibliography:

Greetham, David. "Uncoupled: OR, How I Lost My Author(s)." Textual Cultures: Texts, Contexts, Interpretation, vol. 3 no. 1, 2008, p. 45-46. Project MUSE, doi:10.2979/tex.2008.3.1.44.

Our relationship with the authors of the works we read can often be “obscured not by a "cloak of print" but by the veil of scribal confusion and mis-transmission” (Greetham 45-46).

annotator_metadata.Steps:
1. Use search engine to search for "OpenCV change log".
2. Open the top result from GitHub and search the page for "Mask-RCNN".
3. Observe that support for Mask-RCNN model was added in OpenCV version 4.0.0.
4. Expand the two lists of contributors for version 4.0.0.
5. Go to the Wikipedia page for head of government. 
6. Scan through and note that for China, the head of government is the premier.
7. Go to the Wikipedia page for premier of the People's Republic of China.
8. Go to the linked page for List of premiers of the People's Republic of China.
9. Compare the list of OpenCV version 4.0.0 contributors' names and the list of premiers of China to find that Li Peng is present in both lists.

Physical constraint (location): The papers' authors, Omar Valencfia-Mendez and G. Curt Fiedler, are not directly related to physical locations, but the context implies that the shrimp and sea star were likely studied in marine environments.
Dependency constraint: The problem relies on the availability of data from both papers as prerequisites for calculation.
Contextual detail: The problem requires understanding the contents and specific data presented in each paper.

1. Searched "Omar Valencfia-Mendez 2017 shrimp paper" on Google.
2. Opened "Decapoda: Palaemonidae: Hymenocera picta Dana, 1852) ..." on https://www.threatenedtaxa.org/index.php/JoTT/article/view/3238.
3. Clicked "PDF/A".
4. Found the length of the recorded shrimp as TL in the paper (4.5cm).
5. Searched "G. Curt Fiedler 2002 shrimp paper" on Google.
6. Opened "(PDF) The influence of social environment on sex ..." on https://www.researchgate.net/publication/232696279_The_influence_of_social_environment_on_sex_determination_in_harlequin_shrimp_Hymenocera_picta_Decapoda_Gnathophyllidae.
7. Found the size of the sea star fed to the shrimp (1cm).
8. Took the percentage (1 / 4.5 * 100% = 22.22222%).
9. Rounded to the nearest integer (22%).

problem: What animals that were mentioned in both Ilias Lagkouvardos's and Olga Tapia's papers on the alvei species of the genus named for Copenhagen outside the bibliographies were also present in the 2021 article cited on the alvei species' Wikipedia page about a multicenter, randomized, double-blind study?
constraints: Time constraint: The problem refers to a specific year (2021), indicating a deadline or time frame for consideration.
Resource constraint: No specific resources are mentioned, but it can be inferred that there are limited bibliographies and papers from Lagkouvardos and Tapia to consider.
Dependency constraint: The presence of an animal in both Lagkouvardos's and Tapia's papers is a prerequisite for considering it in the 2021 article.
Logical constraint: The problem requires identifying animals mentioned in both papers, excluding those listed in bibliographies, and matching them with the 2021 article.
Physical constraint: None relevant to this problem, as it deals with abstract concepts (papers, articles) rather than physical locations or distances.

Contextual detail: Ilias Lagkouvardos's and Olga Tapia's papers are about alvei species of a genus named after Copenhagen; the 2021 article is about a multicenter, randomized, double-blind study on the same topic.
solutions:
Next step: Review Ilias Lagkouvardos's and Olga Tapia's papers on the alvei species to identify the animals mentioned in each paper. Take note of any species that are common between the two papers.
Next step: Verify the results by cross-checking the identified animal species against the 2021 article cited on the Wikipedia page about the multicenter, randomized, double-blind study to determine which ones were also mentioned in this article.

My family reunion is this week, and I was assigned the mashed potatoes to bring. The attendees include my married mother and father, my twin brother and his family, my aunt and her family, my grandma and her brother, her brother's daughter, and his daughter's family. All the adults but me have been married, and no one is divorced or remarried, but my grandpa and my grandma's sister-in-law passed away last year. All living spouses are attending. My brother has two children that are still kids, my aunt has one six-year-old, and my grandma's brother's daughter has three kids under 12. I figure each adult will eat about 1.5 potatoes of mashed potatoes and each kid will eat about 1/2 a potato of mashed potatoes, except my second cousins don't eat carbs. The average potato is about half a pound, and potatoes are sold in 5-pound bags. How many whole bags of potatoes do I need? Just give the number.
constraints: Time constraint: The mashed potatoes need to be prepared and brought to the reunion this week.
Resource constraint: Availability of whole bags of potatoes for purchase.
Dependency constraint: Each adult will eat 1.5 potatoes, and each kid will eat 0.5 potatoes (except second cousins).
Logical constraint: Mashed potatoes are only eaten by adults and kids (no second cousins).
Physical constraint: Potatoes are sold in 5-pound bags.
Quantity constraint: Each adult eats approximately 1.5 potatoes, and each kid eats approximately 0.5 potatoes.

constraints: Family reunion attendees: married mother, father, twin brother and family (kids), aunt and family (one 6-year-old), grandma and her brother, his daughter, and her family (three kids under 12).
Number of adults: 8 (all but me).
Number of kids: 5 (two from my brother's family, one from aunt's family, and three from grandma's brother's daughter's family).
Kids' ages: all under 12.
Second cousins don't eat carbs, so they won't eat mashed potatoes.
Average adult eats 1.5 potatoes of mashed potatoes.
Kids eat 1/2 potato of mashed potatoes (except second cousins).
Potatoes are sold in 5-pound bags.
Average potato is about half a pound.

annotator_metadata.Steps:
1. Calculate the number of adults (mother, father, brother, brother's wife, aunt, aunt's husband, grandma, grandma's brother, grandma's brother's daughter, grandma's brother's daughter's husband, me = 11).
2. Calculate the number of children (niece, nephew, cousin, grandma's brother's daughter's kids x3 = 6).
3. Subtract the number of second cousins (grandma's brother's daughter's kids) (6 - 3 = 3).
4. Calculate the adult potatoes (11 * 1.5 = 16.5).
5. Calculate the child potatoes (3 * 0.5 = 1.5).
6. Add to get the total potatoes (16.5 + 1.5 = 18).
7. Multiply to get the pounds of potatoes (18 * 0.5 = 9 pounds).
8. Calculate the number of 5-lb bags needed (9 / 5 = 1.8).
9. Round up to get total bags (2).

annotator_metadata.Steps:
1. Search the web for “tri rail ridership may 2019”.
2. Click result for Tri-Rail website.
3. Click drop-down for 2019.
4. Click PDF for May 2019 ridership report.
5. Scroll down to find the statistics for each train.
6. Locate the ridership numbers for the 27th, and scroll to find the train with the highest number for that day: train number P685.
7. Search the web for “tri rail schedule may 2019”.
8. Click result for Tri-Rail website.
9. Noticing that the train doesn’t appear on the weekday schedule, click the link for the weekend/holiday schedule. May 27th may have been a holiday.
10. Locate the time that P685 is scheduled to arrive at Pompano Beach: 6:41 PM.
11. To confirm, search “may 2019 holidays”.
12. Verify that May 27th, 2019 was the Memorial Day holiday.
13. Since the Tri-Rail website didn’t give a date for its schedule, search the web for “tri rail schedule changes” to see if the schedule has changed since 2019.
14. The only result mentioning a schedule change dates to 2015, so 6:41 PM seems like the answer.

problem:
In the fictional language of Tizin, basic sentences are arranged with the Verb first, followed by the direct object, followed by the subject of the sentence. I want to express my love for apples to my Tizin friend. 

The word that indicates oneself is "Pa" is the nominative form, "Mato" is the accusative form, and "Sing" is the genitive form. 

The root verb that indicates an intense like for something is "Maktay". When it is used in the present, it is used in it's root form, when it is used in the preterit past, it is "Tay", and when it is used in the imperfect past, it is "Aktay". It is used differently than in English, and is better translated as "is pleasing to", meaning that the thing doing the liking is actually the object of the sentence rather than the subject.

The word for apples is borrowed from English in Tizin, and so it is "Apple" is the nominative form, "Zapple" is the accusative form, and "Izapple" is the genitive form. 

Please translate "I like apples" to Tizin.

annotator_metadata.Steps:
1. I searched for "Metropolitan Museum of Art search collection" using a search engine to get to the "Search the Collection" page on the Metropolitan Museum of Art's website.
2. I selected "Accession Number" in the search field dropdown and entered "29.100.5" into the text input, noting that the only result is a portrait titled "Cardinal Fernando Niño de Guevara (1541–1609)"
3. I went to Fernando Niño de Guevara's Wikipedia page and noted that he was consecrated bishop by Pope Clement VIII with Camillo Borghese and Alfonso Visconti as co-consecrators.
4. I eliminated Pope Clement VIII as the answer since he was obviously a pope based on his title.
5. I went to Camillo Borghese's Wikipedia page and noted that he became Pope Paul V, eliminating him as the answer.
6. I went to Alfonso Visconti's Wikipedia page and noted that he never became pope, so the answer to the question is "Alfonso Visconti".

problem: According to Box Office Mojo's 2020 Worldwide Box Office list, how many of the top 10 highest-grossing worldwide movies are also on the top 10 highest-grossing domestic movies? Your answer should be a numerical integer value.
constraints: Time constraint: The relevant time period is 2020.
Resource constraint: The resource being considered is movies, specifically their grossing amounts.
Logical constraint: The top 10 highest-grossing worldwide movies and the top 10 highest-grossing domestic movies are two separate lists, each with its own ranking.
Dependency constraint: There is no direct dependency between the rankings of the two lists; however, we need to find a common overlap between the two lists.
Physical constraint: No physical constraints apply in this problem, as it only deals with movie rankings and grossing amounts.
Contextual detail: The relevant data comes from Box Office Mojo's 2020 Worldwide Box Office list.
solutions:
Next step: Retrieve the lists of top 10 highest-grossing worldwide and domestic movies from Box Office Mojo's 2020 data. This will provide the foundation for comparing the two lists.
Next step: Compare the titles in the retrieved lists to determine which ones appear in both the worldwide and domestic top 10 lists, effectively identifying the common elements between the two.

problem:
The following numbers function similarly to ISBN 13 numbers, however, their validation methods are slightly different. Rather than using alternate weights of 1 and 3, the checksum digit is calculated with an alternate weight of 1 and some other positive integer less than 10. Otherwise, the checksum digit is calculated as expected. Unfortunately, there is an error in the data. Two adjacent columns have been transposed. These errored columns do not involve the final column or one of the first three columns. Using this information, please provide all potential solutions with the unknown weight and the smaller index of the two errored columns (assume we start our indexing at 0 and ignore hyphens). Give your answer in the form x, y where x is the weight and y is the smaller index of the two transposed columns.

978-354181391-9
978-946669746-1
978-398036139-6
978-447656680-4
978-279586664-7
978-595073693-3
978-976647652-6
978-591178125-5
978-728465924-5
978-414825155-9
constraints: The ISBN numbers have 13 digits in total.
Two adjacent columns (columns) have been transposed, but not involving the final column or one of the first three columns.
The transposition error does not affect the first three or last columns.
The weight used for checksum calculation is an alternate weight of 1 and some other positive integer less than 10.

annotator_metadata.Steps:
1. Searched "volume from pressure, temperature, mass" on Google.
2. Opened the "Specific Volume: Definition, Formulas, Examples - ThoughtCo" page.
3. Noted that PV = nRT where V is volume, R is the ideal gas constant, T is temperature, P is pressure, and M is moles.
4. Followed the "gas constant" link.
5. Noted that R = 8.31446261815324 J/K-mol.
6. Searched "Freon-12" on Google.
7. Opened the "Dichlorodifluoromethane" on Wikipedia.
8. Noted the molar mass of 120.91 g/mol.
9. Converted 0.312 kg = 312 g.
10. Calculated moles: 312 g / 120.91 g/mol = 2.58 mol.
11. Searched "Marianas Trench pressure" on Google.
12. Noted the pressure in the featured text snippet of 15,750 psi.
13. Searched "psi to atm" on Google.
14. Noted 1 psi = 0.068046 atm.
15. Converted psi to atm: 15,750 * 0.068046 = 1071.7245 atm.
16. Searched "Marianas Trench temperature" on Google.
17. Noted the temperature range from 34-39F.
18. Searched "F to K" on Google.
19. Noted that K equals F plus 459.67 times 5/9 from the conversion tool.
20. Converted temperature to K: 39 + 459.67 * 5/9 = 277.039K.
21. Searched "joules to atm" on Google and noted the conversion of 1 Joule = 0.0098692326671601 Liter Atmosphere from the featured text snippet.
22. Converted 8.31446261815324 * 0.0098692326671601 = 0.08205736608096 L-atm/K-mol.
21. Changed PV = nRT to V = nRT/P
22. Plugged numbers into the ideal gas equation: V = (0.08205736608096 L-atm/K-mol * 277.039K * 2.58 mol) / (1071.7245 atm) = 0.05473 L.
23. Converted to mL: 0.05473 L = 54.73.
24. Rounded to the nearest mL.

annotator_metadata.Steps:
1. Searched "NIH translation 1913 Michaelis-Menten Paper" on Google.
2. Opened "The Original Michaelis Constant: Translation of the 1913 Michaelis-Menten Paper" on the NIH website.
3. Scrolled down to the final equation: v = (km ⋅ [S]) / (1 + (km/kcat) ⋅ [S]).
4. Opened the Excel file.
5. Searched "Michaelis-Menten equation" on Google to find the meaning of the variables.
6. Opened the Wikipedia "Michaelis–Menten kinetics" page.
7. Noted v = reaction rate (velocity of reaction) and kcat = catalytic rate constant (catalytic constant).
8. Returned to the NIH paper and found km = Menten constant and [S] = substrate concentration.
9. Plugged reaction 7's values from the Excel file into the equation: v = (0.052 * 72.3) / (1 + (0.052 / 0.0429) * 72.3) = 0.042416.
10. Rounded to four decimal places (0.0424).

You are a telecommunications engineer who wants to build cell phone towers on a stretch of road. In the reference file is a layout of the road and nearby houses. Each dash, "-", is a marker indicating a mile. Each capital H indicates a house located next to a mile marker, appearing above or below the stretch of road. Each cell phone tower can cover houses located next to the road within a 4-mile radius. Find the minimum number of cell phone towers needed to cover all houses next to the road. Your answer should be a positive numerical integer value.
constraints: The road stretch has markers at every mile, represented by dashes ("-").
Each capital H indicates a house located next to the road.
Houses can be above or below the road.
Cell phone towers can cover houses within a 4-mile radius from their location.
The goal is to find the minimum number of cell phone towers needed to cover all houses next to the road.

constraints: Each dash "-" represents a mile marker on the stretch of road.
Capital letters "H" indicate houses located next to a mile marker, appearing above or below the road.
The stretch of road has a finite length and can be divided into segments marked by dashes "-".
Cell phone towers can only be built at specific locations along the road, corresponding to dash markers ("-").
Each cell phone tower can cover houses located next to the road within a 4-mile radius from its location.
Houses must be covered by a cell phone tower to ensure signal reception; therefore, all houses near the road must be within range of at least one cell phone tower.
The minimum number of cell phone towers required is an integer value (positive whole number).
The physical distance between cell phone towers and houses along the road affects their coverage capabilities.
No house can be covered by more than one cell phone tower; each house must be within range of a single tower.

annotator_metadata.Steps:
1. Determine the diameter of each cell phone tower's coverage: 2 x 4 miles radius = 8 miles diameter.
2. Use the diameter to maximize the coverage of each tower by capturing houses 4 miles to the left and 4 miles to the right.
3. Start from the furthest left side of the road at the first house.
4. Place the first tower 4 miles in to cover the first house.
5. Move forward 4 miles from the first tower. The first tower also covers the house above mile marker 8. 
6. Find the next uncovered house below mile marker 12.
7. Move 4 miles in from the uncovered house and place a second tower. The house is now covered. 
8. Move forward 4 miles from the second tower. The second tower also covers the house above mile marker 16.
9. Find the next uncovered house below mile marker 25.
10. Move 4 miles in from the uncovered house and place a third tower. The third tower also covers the house above marker 28.
11. Move forward 4 miles from the third tower. The third tower also covers the last house below marker 30.
12. The final number of cell phone towers erected is 3.

f(-5) = (-5)^3 + 4(-5)^2 - 3(-5) + 8 = -125 + 100 - 15 + 8 = -132

x1 = x0 - f(x0) / f'(x0)
= (-5) - (-132) / 32
= (-5) - (4.125)
= -9.125

problem:
You are Van Helsing, a renowned vampire hunter. A Count of Moldova, Lațcu IV, son of  Costea, has tasked you with investigating the village of Șirnea in neighboring Wallachia. The Count's advisors have reported that a vampire was spotted crossing the border near the village, and would like you to investigate it.

You travel to the village of Șirnea, and you begin your investigation. One night, just before dawn, you catch a glimpse of a man in a long black cape with red lining leaping from roof-top to roof-top with superhuman agility. It's a vampire! You try to chase the creature back to its home, but the creature is too fast. However, because of the remoteness of the village, you know with absolute certainty that the vampire must be a resident of the village. You decide that your best course of action will be to visit all 100 residents of the town during the day. You know something about vampires and humans that will make your investigation possible; humans always tell the truth, but vampires always lie.

In the afternoon, you go from house to house, speaking with all 100 residents of Șirnea. You ask everyone the same question: "How many vampires are living in Șirnea". Everyone in the village gives the same response, "At least one of us is a human."

How many residents of Șirnea have been turned into vampires?
constraints: Time constraint: The investigation must be completed during daylight hours (before sunset).
Resource constraint: Van Helsing has access to 100 residents of the village.
Dependency constraint: Humans always tell the truth, while vampires always lie.
Logical constraint: At least one resident is a human (all 100 residents gave the same response).
Physical constraint: The vampire must be a resident of the village.
solutions:
Since all 100 residents give the same response ("At least one of us is a human"), and humans always tell the truth, we can deduce that at least one resident is indeed human. 

Next step: Try to identify which resident is the human among the 100.

steps:
Next step: 

Since all 100 residents give the same response ("At least one of us is a human"), it means that every resident you've asked, including the vampire(s), is telling the truth. As humans always tell the truth, this statement must be true for at least some of the villagers. However, since vampires always lie, the statement "At least one of us is a human" cannot include any vampires. 

Consider the following: if there were only one vampire in the village, they would say there are no humans to avoid revealing their own existence. This implies that there must be at least two humans in the village, as each human will claim there's at least one other human.

problem:
I thought we could try a fun word puzzle together :)

I've got a Boggle board here:

ABRL
EITE
IONS
FPEI

I'd like to know the longest word that can be generated from the board. Please find the longest English language word that can be generated from this board. If more than one word of the same length exists at the maximum word length, please report the longest word that comes first, alphabetically. Oh, and I know that there might be different wordlists available for Boggle, so let's please just use the words_alpha dictionary found at https://github.com/dwyl/english-words as the dictionary for our game.
constraints: The Boggle board consists of 4 rows: ABRL, EITE, IONS, FPEI.
The goal is to find the longest English language word that can be generated from this board using the words_alpha dictionary found at https://github.com/dwyl/english-words.
All words must be formed using letters from the Boggle board without reusing any letter more times than it appears on the board.
The search for the longest word is case-insensitive, as the problem does not specify whether to consider uppercase or lowercase letters.
The dictionary used is the words_alpha dictionary, which may contain variations in word forms (e.g., singular vs. plural) and verb tenses.

Step 4: Evaluate the page content and store the game's rules:

"One player begins the game by shaking a covered tray of 16 cubic dice, each with a different letter printed on each of its sides. The dice settle into a 4×4 tray so that only the top letter of each cube is visible. After they have settled into the tray, a three-minute sand timer is started and all players simultaneously begin the main phase of play.[3]

Each player searches for words that fit the following criteria:

Words must be at least three letters in length.
Each letter after the first must be a horizontal, vertical, or diagonal neighbor of the one before it.
No individual letter cube may be used more than once in a word.
No capitalized or hyphenated words are allowed.
Multiple forms of the same word are allowed, such as singular/plural forms and other derivations. Each player records all the words they find by writing on a private sheet of paper. After three minutes have elapsed, all players must immediately stop writing and the game enters the scoring phase.

In this, each player reads off their list of discovered words. If two or more players wrote the same word, it is removed from all players' lists. Any player may challenge the validity of a word, in which case a previously nominated dictionary is used to verify or refute it. Once all duplicates and invalid words have been eliminated, points are awarded based on the length of each remaining word in a player's list. The winner is the player whose point total is highest, with any ties typically broken by a count of long words."

Step 5: Using a web browser, navigate to the nominated dictionary specified by my user, https://github.com/dwyl/english-words
Step 6: Navigate to the linked page, https://github.com/dwyl/english-words/blob/master/words_alpha.txt
Step 7: Download the words_alpha.txt dictionary and save it to my file system as "words_alpha.txt"
Step 8: Using a Python IDE, create a new project to solve the user's request as specified
Step 9: Compose a Python program that accepts an input string and prints an output of all words that can be generated that match words in the nominated dictionary. The program must observe the rules discovered in Step 4. The output should be sorted so that strings are sorted alphabetically and grouped by character count:

class Boggle_Solver:
    def __init__(self, file, size=4, points=None):
        self.size = size
        self.board = [[' '] * self.size for _ in range(self.size)]
        self.adjacency = self.build_adjacency()
        self.words, self.prefixes = self.load_dictionary(file)
        
    def adjacent(self, pos):
        row, col = pos
        adj = []
        for i in [-1, 0, 1]:
            for j in [-1, 0, 1]:
                new_row = row + i
                new_col = col + j
                if 0 <= new_row < self.size and 0 <= new_col < self.size and not (i == j == 0):
                    adj.append((new_row, new_col))
        return adj

    def build_adjacency(self):
        adjacency = dict()
        for row in range(0, self.size):
            for col in range(0, self.size):
                adjacency[(row, col)] = self.adjacent((row, col))
        return adjacency

    def load_dictionary(self, file):
        words = set()
        prefixes = set()
        with open(file, 'r') as f:
            next(f)
            for line in f:
                word = line.rstrip()
                if len(word) >= 3:
                    words.add(word)
                    for i in range(len(word)):
                        prefixes.add(word[:i])
        return words, prefixes

    def get_letter(self, pos):
        return self.board[pos[0]][pos[1]]
     
    def set_board(self, letters):
        board_input=letters.lower()
        for row in range(self.size):
            index = row * self.size
            row_letters = board_input[index:index+self.size]
            for col, letter in enumerate(row_letters):
                self.board[row][col] = letter
     
    def find_words(self):
        words = set()
        for row in range(self.size):
            for col in range(self.size):
                words |= self.find_words_pos((row, col))
        return sorted(words, key=lambda x: (-len(x), x))
    
    def find_words_pos(self, pos):
        stack = [(n, [pos], self.get_letter(pos)) for n in self.adjacency[pos]]
        words = set()
        while stack:
            curr, path, chars = stack.pop()
            curr_char = self.get_letter(curr)
            curr_chars = chars + curr_char

            if curr_chars in self.words:
                words.add(curr_chars)

            if curr_chars in self.prefixes:
                curr_adj = self.adjacency[curr]
                stack.extend([(n, path + [curr], curr_chars) for n in curr_adj if n not in path])
        return words

if __name__ == '__main__':
    word_list = Boggle_Solver('words_alpha.txt')
    word_list.set_board('ABRLEITEIONSFPEI')
    print(word_list.find_words())

problem: According to the World Bank, which countries had gross savings of over 35% of GDP for every year in the period 2001-2010? Give your answer as a comma-separated list of countries in alphabetical order. Use the countries most common names in english when answering.
constraints: Time constraint: The period is specified to be 2001-2010.
Resource constraint (data): The World Bank provides gross savings data for various countries during this period.
Logical constraint: Countries with gross savings of over 35% of GDP are sought.
Dependency constraint (prerequisite): Each country must have been recorded as having gross savings above 35% of GDP for every year within the specified period (2001-2010).
Physical constraint (distance/location): Not applicable in this problem, as it's focused on economic data and not geographical distances or locations.
solutions:
Next step: Consult the World Bank's official data, specifically the World Development Indicators (WDI) dataset for 2001-2010, and extract the list of countries with gross savings exceeding 35% of GDP for each year in that period.
Next step: Download or access the WDI dataset for 2001-2010 from the World Bank's website and extract the relevant data fields (e.g., country name, GDP, and gross savings) into a spreadsheet or database format.
Next step: Filter the extracted data to find countries that had gross savings of over 35% of GDP for every year in the period 2001-2010.

annotator_metadata.Steps:
1. Use search engine to search for "World Bank gross savings % of GDP".
2. Open World Bank data webpage showing gross savings as % of GDP (https://data.worldbank.org/indicator/NY.GNS.ICTR.ZS).
3. Download data from webpage as Excel file and open it in a spreadsheet editor like Microsoft Excel.
4. Go to the file's "Data" sheet.
5. Add columns with formulas indicating if the gross savings % of GDP figures in each of the years from 2001 to 2010 are greater than 35 for each row.
6. Add column computing AND of the boolean values from the previous step for each row.
7. Filter for rows where the output of the AND from the previous step is true.
8. Get the list of country names in the remaining rows, excluding non-country regions and categories.
9. Sort the list alphabetically and format it as a comma-separated list to get the final answer: Brunei Darussalam, China, Morocco, Singapore
annotator_metadata.Tools:
1. Web browser
2. Search engine
3. Spreadsheet editor

problem:
I'm making a grocery list for my mom, but she's a professor of botany and she's a real stickler when it comes to categorizing things. I need to add different foods to different categories on the grocery list, but if I make a mistake, she won't buy anything inserted in the wrong category. Here's the list I have so far:

milk, eggs, flour, whole bean coffee, Oreos, sweet potatoes, fresh basil, plums, green beans, rice, corn, bell pepper, whole allspice, acorns, broccoli, celery, zucchini, lettuce, peanuts

I need to make headings for the fruits and vegetables. Could you please create a list of just the vegetables from my list? If you could do that, then I can figure out how to categorize the rest of the list into the appropriate categories. But remember that my mom is a real stickler, so make sure that no botanical fruits end up on the vegetable list, or she won't get them when she's at the store. Please alphabetize the list of vegetables, and place each item in a comma separated list.

annotator_metadata.Steps:
1. Searched "August Wikipedia" on Google search.
2. Opened the Wikipedia page for the month of August.
3. Clicked on "View history" on the "August 1" page.
4. Went back to the last edited version prior to July 2023.
5. Checked the references for Twitter posts.
6. Repeated the process for each day of August.
7. Counted the Twitter posts found.

annotator_metadata.Steps:
1. Use search engine to search for "2008 painting Embroidery from Uzbekistan".
2. Open the top result, a link to the painting's page on the Dayton Art Institute website, and verify that the painting has the specified title and year.
3. Identify the fruits in the painting as watermelon, pear, lemon, and banana, which can be verified by either watching the video on the page or reading its linked transcript.
4. Use search engine to search for "ocean liner floating prop The Last Voyage".
5. Note from the results that this ocean liner was the SS Île de France.
6. Use search engine to search for "October 1949 breakfast menu SS Île de France".
7. Go to the result that shows the vintage SS Île de France breakfast menu for October 1949.
8. Search the menu for each of the four fruits from the painting, finding "Pear" and "Bananas" but no matches for "lemon" or "watermelon".
9. Check the positions of the fruits in the painting to find that the pears come before the bananas in clockwise order starting from the 12 o'clock position.
10. Format the final answer as specified using the correct ordering: pears, bananas

problem:
Hi, I'm making a pie but I could use some help with my shopping list. I have everything I need for the crust, but I'm not sure about the filling. I got the recipe from my friend Aditi, but she left it as a voice memo and the speaker on my phone is buzzing so I can't quite make out what she's saying. Could you please listen to the recipe and list all of the ingredients that my friend described? I only want the ingredients for the filling, as I have everything I need to make my favorite pie crust. I've attached the recipe as Strawberry pie.mp3.

In your response, please only list the ingredients, not any measurements. So if the recipe calls for "a pinch of salt" or "two cups of ripe strawberries" the ingredients on the list would be "salt" and "ripe strawberries".

Please format your response as a comma separated list of ingredients. Also, please alphabetize the ingredients.

problem: It's May 2023, and I'm about to drive across the U.S. from California to Maine. I always recycle my water bottles at the end of a trip, and I drink 5 12-ounce water bottles for every 100 miles I travel, rounded to the nearest 100. Assuming I follow I-40 from Los Angeles to Cincinnati, then take I-90 from Cincinnati to Augusta, how many dollars will I get back according to Wikipedia?
constraints: Travel duration: The trip will be completed within a certain timeframe (May 2023).
Distance constraint: The distance from California to Maine is approximately 2,796 miles (according to Google Maps).
Water consumption constraint: Drink 5 12-ounce water bottles for every 100 miles traveled, rounded to the nearest 100.
Route constraint: Follow I-40 from Los Angeles to Cincinnati, then take I-90 from Cincinnati to Augusta.
Time-based constraint: The trip will be completed within a specific time frame (May 2023).
Resource constraint: Availability of fuel and money for the trip is assumed.
Logical constraint: Recycling water bottles at the end of the trip is a given.
solutions:
Next step: Determine the total distance of your trip by calculating the mileage between California and Maine. This will help you estimate the number of water bottles you'll consume during the journey, which is relevant to the recycling question.
Next step: Measure the mileage from Los Angeles (California) to Augusta (Maine) using a mapping tool or road trip planner to get an accurate total distance for your trip. This will help you calculate the number of water bottles consumed and ultimately, the amount of money you'll recycle.

annotator_metadata.Steps:
1. Looked up the route from Los Angeles to Cincinnati on Google.
2. Noted the miles (2,180 mi) and the states traveled.
3. Looked up the route from Cincinnati to Augusta on Google.
4. Noted the miles (1,035.4 mi) and the states traveled.
5. Searched "us bottle deposit" on Google.
6. Opened the "Container deposit legislation in the United States" page on Wikipedia.
7. Clicked "View history" for the page.
8. Opened the last version from May 2023.
9. Found Maine's bottle deposit as of May 2023 (5 cents)
10. Added the miles (2,180 + 1,035 = 3,215).
11. Rounded the miles to the nearest 100 (3,200).
12. Calculated the number of bottles (3,200 / 100 = 32, 32 * 5 = 160 bottles).
13. Multiplied bottles by bottle deposit (160 * 5 = 800).
14. Converted cents to dollars ($8).

problem:
Bob was invited to participate in a game show, and he advanced to the final round. The final round offered Bob the chance to win a large sum by playing a game against the host. The host has 30 shiny prop coins, each of which is worth $1,000 if Bob manages to win them by playing the game. The host hides the coins in three different prize boxes and then shuffles their order. The only rule restricting the host's coin placement is that one box must contain at least 2 coins, and one box must contain 6 more coins than another box. In order to play, Bob must submit three guesses, one guess for the number of coins in each box. The box is then opened and the number of coins is revealed. If Bob's guess is a number greater than the number of coins in the box, Bob earns no coins. If Bob guesses a number equal to or less than the number of coins in the box, Bob wins a number of coins equal to his guess.

If Bob plays uses the optimal strategy, what's the minimum amount of money he can win from the game?

annotator_metadata.Steps:
1. Go to the Wikipedia page for "United States secretary of homeland security".
2. Open the Wikipedia pages for each person who held the position of United States secretary of homeland security in a non-acting capacity prior to April 2019.
3. Using the infobox on each person's Wikipedia page, open the Wikipedia page for the university from which each person received a bachelor's degree (bachelor's degree indicated by AB, BA, or BS).
4. Comparing the longitude coordinates for each university given on their Wikipedia pages, note that Santa Clara University is the westernmost as it has the highest longitude value in degrees W.
5. Note that the easternmost is either Harvard University or University of Massachusetts Boston, but the longitude for Harvard University is expressed in degrees, minutes, and seconds (71°07′01″W) while the longitude for University of Massachusetts Boston is expressed in decimal degrees (71.038445°W), requiring conversion to determine which is further east.
6. Convert 71°07′01″W to decimal degrees using the formula [decimal degrees] = [degrees] + [minutes] / 60 + [seconds] / 3600 to get approximately 71.1169°W for Harvard's longitude, which is further west than the University of Massachusetts Boston's longitude.
7. Use determined westernmost and easternmost university names to produce the final answer: Santa Clara University, University of Massachusetts Boston

problem: A 5-man group made up of one tank, one healer, and three DPS is doing a dungeon that was just released in World of Warcraft. Two are plate wearers and two are cloth wearers. At the final boss, both the tank and the healer are casting holy spells. Ice and fire are being used, each one by a different DPS. A bear from the group is attacking the boss. Metamorphosis is cast. The Kilt of the Forgotten One drops as loot, but no one can use it. If all classes were using their class abilities and all classes are unique, what are the five classes in the group in alphabetical order separated by commas?
constraints: The group consists of 5 members: 1 tank, 1 healer, and 3 DPS.
There are two plate wearers in the group.
There are two cloth wearers in the group.
The tank and the healer are casting holy spells at the final boss.
Two different DPS members are using ice and fire abilities, respectively.
A bear from the group is attacking the boss.
Metamorphosis has been cast.
The Kilt of the Forgotten One drops as loot, but no one can use it.
Each class has a unique set of abilities.

constraints: The group consists of 5 players with distinct classes.
There is one tank and one healer among the five players.
Three DPS (damage-per-second) players are present, each using a different type of damage (ice or fire).
Two players wear plate armor, while two others wear cloth armor.
The final boss fight involves both the tank and the healer casting holy spells.
A player with a bear form is attacking the boss during the fight.
Metamorphosis is cast during the encounter.
The Kilt of the Forgotten One drops as loot, but no one can use it.

gaia_metadata.ground_truth: Death Knight, Hunter, Paladin, Priest, Warlock

annotator_metadata.Steps:
1. Searched "WoW classes" on Google.
2. Opened "https://worldofwarcraft.blizzard.com/en-us/game/classes".
3. Made an alphabetical list of all WoW classes: Death Knight, Demon Hunter, Druid, Evoker, Hunter, Mage, Monk, Paladin, Priest, Rogue, Shaman, Warlock, and Warrior.
4. Opened each page and noted the armor type: Death Knight (plate), Demon Hunter (leather), Druid (leather), Evoker (mail), Hunter (mail), Mage (cloth), Monk (leather), Paladin (plate), Priest (cloth), Rogue (leather), Shaman (mail), Warlock (cloth), and Warrior (plate).
5. Looked up "Kilt of the Forgotten One" on Google.
6. Opened https://www.wowhead.com/wotlk/item=37616/kilt-of-the-forgotten-one.
7. Noted that it is leather, and none of the classes can use it, so the remaining classes are: Death Knight (plate), Evoker (mail), Hunter (mail), Mage (cloth), Paladin (plate), Priest (cloth), Shaman (mail), Warlock (cloth), and Warrior (plate).
8. Noted that it was added in Wrath of the Lich King, so if the dungeon is newly released, the era is the Wrath of the Lich King expansion.
9. Searched "Wrath of the Lich King class abilities" on Google.
10. Opened https://www.wowhead.com/wotlk/spells/abilities.
11. Sorted by class and noted that Evokers, Demon Hunters, and Monks did not exist yet, so the remaining classes are: Death Knight (plate), Hunter (mail), Mage (cloth), Paladin (plate), Priest (cloth), Shaman (mail), Warlock (cloth), and Warrior (plate).
12. Checked which classes use Holy school abilities, Paladin (plate) and Priest (cloth), so they must be in the group as tank and healer.
13. Checked which classes use ice (Frost) and fire abilities, Death Knight (plate), Mage (cloth), Shaman (mail), and Warlock (cloth).
14. There can only be one other plate class, so it must be Death Knight or Warrior, and one other cloth class, so it must be Mage or Warlock.
15. Metamorphosis is a Warlock ability in Wrath of the Lich King, so it must be the other cloth class, and the group so far is Paladin, Priest, Warlock, plate DPS, and other DPS, with remaining options of Death Knight (plate), Hunter (mail), Mage (cloth), Shaman (mail), and Warrior (plate).
16. There cannot be another cloth class, so the remaining options are Death Knight (plate), Hunter (mail), Shaman (mail), and Warrior (plate).
17. There is a bear attacking the boss and there is no Druid to shapeshift into a bear, so it must be a Hunter's pet, making the group Paladin, Priest, Warlock, Hunter, and plate DPS, with remaining options of Death Knight (plate), Hunter (mail), Mage (cloth), Shaman (mail), and Warrior (plate).
18. The last class is plate, leaving only Death Knight and Warrior.
19. Hunters and Warlocks can both cast Fire abilities but cannot cast Frost abilities, so the last DPS must cast ice (Frost) abilities, making the last DPS a Frost Death Knight since Warriors have no Frost abilities.
20. Order the group alphabetically: Death Knight, Hunter, Paladin, Priest, Warlock.

annotator_metadata.Steps:
1. Open the image.
2. Search "butterfat wikipedia" on Google search.
3. Open the Butterfat Wikipedia page.
4. Click "View history" on the page.
5. Scroll down to the end of 2020 and click the last 2020 version of the page.
6. Check the ice cream requirement for fat content (10%).
7. Click "View history" on the page.
8. Scroll down to the beginning of 2020 and click the last 2019 version of the page.
9. Check the ice cream requirement for fat content to ensure it's the same (10%).
10. Calculate the fat percentage of the pint of ice cream from the image of the nutrition panel (21g fat per serving / 144g ice cream per serving = 14.6%).
11. Calculate the difference from the standard (14.6% - 10% = 4.6%).

4. Search engine

annotator_metadata.Steps:
Step 1: Conduct a web search for the Goldfinger film screenplay.
Step 2: Navigate to the top result, https://www.universalexports.net/scripts/goldfinger.pdf
Step 3: Review the screenplay pdf. Navigate to the final page of the screenplay, looking for mentions and combinations of "conceal" "James" "James Bond" "Pussy" "Pussy Galore"
Step 4: After reviewing the line: "Bond grabs the edge of the parachute and pulls it over them." search the rest of the screenplay for any description of the parachute.
Step 5: Failing to locate a description of the parachute in the screenplay, conduct a web search for "James Bond Goldfinger parachute"

The relevant information from the video is the two-minute mark at which the hosts are competing on the track.
